tossups.answer: elf [or elves; accept dark or light elves or svartálfar or Dökkálfar or Ljósálfar]

parts: Name this Central Asian country where geologists set fire to the Darvaza crater in 1971 to prevent the spread of methane gas. This country’s Galkynysh Gas Field is the second-largest in the world after Iran’s South Pars field.
Turkmenistan has sought to boost tourism to the Darvaza crater and to the Awaza resort on this largest inland body of water, which is fed by the Volga River.
The Darvaza crater and Turkmenistan’s gas reserves are located in this desert named for its dark subsurface soil, where a namesake canal carries water to irrigate cotton-growing oases like Mary.

answers: Impressionism [or Impression, Sunrise; or Impression, soleil levant]
parts: Name this hometown where an artist started out by selling caricatures for twenty francs. At an exhibition at the former studio of the photographer Nadar, a painting of this town was unfavorably compared to unfinished wallpaper.
That painting of Le Havre’s harbor by Claude Monet lends its name to this artistic movement that aimed to depict fleeting changes in light and color.
Boudin taught Monet to paint in this manner, which was made easier by the box easel and pochade box. This technique of painting outdoors has a two or three-word French name.

answers: delta-G [or the change in the Gibbs free energy; do not accept or prompt on “Gibbs free energy” or “G”]
parts: Name this constant symbolized with an uppercase K, which is calculated by dividing products by reactants. Comparing the reaction quotient to this value gives the direction of a reaction.
Negative RT times the natural logarithm of the equilibrium constant is equal to this value.

Negative one over the equilibrium constant for ligand dissociation equals the slope on one of these plots. The x-axis on these plots show the concentration of bound radioligand, and on the y is bound over free radioligand.

answers: coherentism [accept coherence theory or any word form]
parts: Identify this epistemic view, according to which the reason for believing some proposition is related to the reasons you might have for believing other related propositions.
This philosopher’s 1912 work The Problems of Philosophy argued against coherence theory by pointing out that coherentists presuppose the laws of logic, which themselves do not cohere with anything.

Haack has argued repeatedly against Rorty’s interpretation of this philosopher. This author of “How to Make Our Ideas Clear” and “The Fixation of Belief” is generally held to be the founder of Pragmatism.

Name this British official who is tarred and feathered in Boston by a mob led by a man with his face painted red and black. This man promises the youth Robin a job, but Robin realizes he can succeed without this relative.

In a story by the author of “My Kinsman, Major Molineux,” this woman works in the lethal garden of her scientist father Giacomo, which turns her poisonous. This woman dies when her lover Giovanni tries to give her an antidote.

This author of “My Kinsman, Major Molineux” and “Rappacini’s Daughter” also created a man who turns to stone in “The Man of Adamant” and a man who dies after giving a sermon on a scaffold, Arthur Dimmesdale.

Name this city located in modern-day Lebanon that dominated Phoenician trade along with Tyre and Sidon. A Roman-era historian from this city named Philo translated the Phoenician history of Sanchuniathon.
The name of Byblos bears great resemblance to the Greek word for “book” possibly because it was a center for the export of this Egyptian reed used for writing materials.

The undeciphered pre-Phoenician Byblos syllabary bears a close relationship to the hieratic script of this Egyptian period. Pharaohs during this period built the Pyramids at Giza and employed Imhotep.
Name this father of Cabarakan and Zipacna whose K’iche name was Vucub-Caquix (“WOO-cub KA-kix”). He tore off the arm of Hunaphu (“HU-nah-pu”).
Seven-Macaw was defeated by the Hero Twins of this myth system, whose main epic, the Popol Vuh, describes adventures in the underworld Xibalba (“shee-BALL-buh”).

Seven-Macaw’s son Zipacna mocks a group of this many boys for their inability to lift a column, prompting them to attempt to kill him with it. Huitzilopochtli (“WEET-see-loh-POACH-tlee”) prepares to kill this many brothers named the Centzonuitznaua (“SENT-so-nweetz-NOW-uh”) and his sister Coyolxauhqui (“coh-YOHL-shau-kee”) at his birth.

answers: he can ignore the day’s topic while telling his story [accept equivalents]
parts: Name this author who created the storytelling Panfilo, Pampinea, and Filostrato in the Decameron.
This “patient” character in the Decameron is tested by her husband Gualtieri, who pretends to kill their children and marry his twelve-year-old daughter.
Description acceptable. The last of the ten storytellers from the Decameron, Dioneo, had this special right when telling stories because of his wit.

answers: Heisenberg uncertainty principle [prompt on Heisenberg principle]
canonical commutation relation [or fundamental commutation prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this statement which makes it impossible to measure two conjugate operators, such as position and momentum, to arbitrary precision.

The position and momentum operators obey this general relation, which states that x times p minus p times x equals i times h-bar. This type of relation holds for any conjugate observables subject to the uncertainty principle.

A specific case of this theorem relates the expectation value of momentum to mass times the time derivative of position. More generally, this theorem states that expectation values of position and momentum operators obey classical laws.

answers: Félix Houphouët-Boigny (“oo-FWAY bwan-YEE”) [do not accept or prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this country which holds the largest church in the world, the Basilica of Our Lady of Peace, in its capital of Yamoussoukro.

This longtime president lavished funds on the building of the Basilica in his hometown. This dictator opposed Ahmed Sekou Toure and Kwame Nkrumah and invested in cocoa and coffee to spearhead the “Ivorian Miracle.”
Houphouët-Boigny was the chief African ally of this European country, who pursued a policy of close alliance with former colonies like Cote d’Ivoire.

In Amsterdam, Dietrich Nikolaus Winkel invented this device for keeping musical time, though he called it a “musical chronometer.” Winkel neglected to patent this device, so the German inventor Johann Maelzel got credit.

This Dutch early baroque composer served as organist at Amsterdam’s Oude Kerk from 1580 until his death, during which time he composed pioneering echo fantasias and Variations on “Mein junges Leben hat ein End.”

While in Amsterdam, François and Pieter Hemony perfected this instrument, which uses a keyboard to ring bells suspended in a tower. The Netherlands gifted one of these instruments to the US which is now in Arlington Cemetery.

Identify this institution where a leader faced a wall for nine years after being initially refused entry. That leader of this institution left some books behind in a chest which his students later found.
That aforementioned teacher was this patriarch of Chan, or Zen Buddhism, known for spreading it to China.

Bodhidharma was erroneously held to have brought this sport into common practice at the monastery. A group of men forming the “Society of Righteous and Harmonious Fists” led a rebellion named for this sport during the Qing dynasty.

answers: Soviet Union [or USSR; prompt on Russia]
parts: Name this lieutenant colonel who in 1942 led sixteen B25 bombers off the USS Hornet to strike the Japanese home islands before bailing out over China.

After bailing out, Doolittle encountered this American officer who helped smuggle Doolittle beyond Japanese lines. Chinese communists killed this missionary eleven days after the end of the war, making him “the first casualty of the Cold War.”
While fifteen of Doolittle’s bombers crash-landed in China, one crew landed in Vladivostok and spent a year interned in this country because of its neutrality pact with Japan.

answers: mourning the dead [accept mourning a family member or attending funerals; be lenient]
parts: Name this process, which requires the father of Olunde to commit ritual suicide in another work.
Tambu fails to mourn the death of her older brother Nhamo because it means there will be money for her to go to missionary school in this novel by Tsitsi Dangarembga (“tuh-SIT-see dan-gar-EMB-gah”).
Elesin’s son Olunde commits ritual suicide to mourn the death of their king in Death and the King’s Horseman, a play by this author.

answers: hydrogen [or H; or H2, or hydrogen gas]
parts: Name this dwarf planet that is orbited by Charon, Nyx, and Hydra. It was formerly the ninth planet from the sun.
This NASA probe flew by Pluto in July 2015. It subsequently studied several Kuiper belt objects, including Ultima Thule.
The New Horizons spacecraft confirmed a “wall” of this substance just beyond the heliopause. At redshift z equals 1089, this substance reionized.

answers: Leopold [or Leopold III; or Leopold II]
School Wars [or Second School War; or First School War]
parts: Give this name of a king who abdicated in 1950 because of a general strike over his 1940 surrender to the Nazis. Adam Hochschild detailed the atrocities of that man’s uncle of the same name in a book on his “ghost.”
This country’s “Royal Question” concerned the political crisis over Leopold III’s fitness for the throne. This country’s region of Flanders supported the king while Wallonia opposed him.

Soon after the Royal Question, this social conflict began after Socialist Leo Collard reversed the subsidies and wage increases of his Christian Social predecessor. The first of these conflicts began after the “Papist Biter” Walthère Frère-Orban passed a sweeping secularization law in 1879.

answers: arousal [or being aroused; prompt on "alertness" or equivalents like "being amped up"]
parts: Name this heightened sensory state caused by activation of the ascending reticular activating system.

An inverted U-shaped law describing the relationship between performance and arousal was developed by this man and John Dillingham Dodson. This man also propagated eugenics by issuing Alpha and Beta intelligence tests to World War I draftees.

Unlike the James-Lange and Cannon-Bard theories of emotion, Jerome Singer and Stanley Schachter proposed that emotions arise from two factors: physiological arousal and this attempt by the mind to causally connect an outside event with the emotion.
Name this author who worked under William Stephenson as a spy in Washington, D. C. His numerous sexual liaisons there possibly inspired his work My Uncle Oswald.

This author used the codenames “Agent 160” and “Astrea” to go on a spying mission to Belgium under King Charles II, as well as a possible trip to Suriname, where a slave uprising may have inspired her novel Oroonoko.
This author of The Power and The Glory drew on his experience as a spy for MI6 to write Our Man in Havana.

answers: PAHs [or polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, or polyaromatic hydrocarbons, prompt on answers mentioning aromatics]
parts: Name this nucleic acid which contains ribose. Its namesake “world” is a hypothetical stage in the evolution of life that preceded cells.

A hypothesis by Simon Platts that supports the RNA world suggests that these organic compounds, which are cosmically abundant, could have catalyzed early polymerization of RNA by stacking alongside RNA.
The term “RNA world” was coined by this scientist, who with Allan Maxam developed a method of DNA sequencing requiring tagging the 5’ (“five-prime”) end with radioactive phosphate.

answers: a ship [or a boat; or Nelson's Ship in a Bottle]
Assyrian empire [or Assyria; or Neo-Assyrian empire]
parts: Katharina Frisch’s Hahn/Cock and Hans Haacke’s Gift Horse were large sculptures created for the Fourth Plinth in what public location?

Yinka Shonibare, who was shortlisted for the Turner Prize, created one of these objects for his Fourth Plinth piece. Turner himself painted one of these objects also present at the Battle of Trafalgar in his Fighting Temeraire.

As of 2019, the Fourth Plinth is occupied by a Michael Rakowitz sculpture made of date cans, which depicts a lamassu from this empire. ISIS destroyed the artifact the piece is based on when they attacked Mosul’s museum in 2015.
